posts.name: Ruhmit Sahu
posts.cooked: Hi! Weâ€™re having a strange issue with our prototype tank drive where the right side motor set goes slower than the left side but only when going forward. Any ideas why?

posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked:
Friction? A way to investigate is to interchange left and right wiring.

If the problem is unchanged, it means â€¦ ? If the problem moves to the other side, it means â€¦?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Which gearboxes and motors are you using?  Do you have a picture of the drive?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Make sure each side of wheels turn manually by hand in a similar way when the robot is unpowered.  Otherwise it probably is a issue assembling gearboxes or otherwise mechanical.

Iâ€™ve seen gearboxes that were assembled with the bosses backwards, and also ones where the press-on rings were somehow too pressed on causing issues before, for example.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
To add to the list:

Are both motors new? Motors will perform slightly differently based on usage and direction of rotation.

If you pot the robot up on blocks, put a mark on the left and right wheels and video it spinning in place for 15seconds (to calculate rpm) is there an appreciable difference between them?

Lastly, is all the visible chain/belt tension the same between the two sides?

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: Do you believe this is a programming or mechanical issue?
My team had a similar problem last year that we found to be due to a loose wire. Not sure if that is your problem but if you canâ€™t find a solution it might be something to check.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
It would definitely be helpful if you would tell us what hardware and software youâ€™re using.

In any case, the first thing to check is hardware.  Put the robot on blocks, power off, and turn the wheels by hand.  Is one side resisting more than the other?    If so, track that down.  There are many possible problems, but the # 1 cause in my experience is a misassembled gearbox.  Many FRC gearboxes feature gears with bosses, which is to say a standoff built into the gear.  These bosses must face the bearings.  More generally, look at whether anything is flat against a bearing somewhere.

If hardware seems OK, check out your controls.  Unplug all but one of your motors, and test to see what happens.  Cycle through each motor.

If youâ€™ve done all that and not found the problem, post as many details as you can, and preferably some video of whatâ€™s going on.

posts.name: Mike Taylor (he/him)
posts.cooked:
This solution is a little bit out there, but it happened to us â€¦

On one side of our drive train, we had installed 13T pinions onto our CIMs.  On the other side were 14T pinions.  We had no idea at the time, they looked pretty much identical, we only discovered the mistake after a full (virtual) season of frustration, when we disassembled to prep for 2022.

posts.name: Ruhmit Sahu
posts.cooked: Thanks to everyone here! We managed to solve the issue by replacing both CIMâ€™s on that side. Really thanks!

posts.name: Rick Lance
posts.cooked: This reminds of when we took apart our gearbox after the season and found that one of the two motors didnâ€™t have a key in the shaft. The drivers told us something wasnâ€™t right, but we just blamed the software.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
Plerion:

We managed to solve the issue by replacing both CIM â€™s on that side.

Follow up on this!  Donâ€™t just put those motors back in the parts box - track down which one is the problem and resolve it, or take both of them permanently out of service (that is, chuck 'em).  You certainly donâ€™t want to swap motors during an event and find out you installed what should have been a known lemon.

posts.name: Ruhmit Sahu
posts.cooked: We found out one motor with bad brushes and marked it as so

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Did you check the pinion gears? If they do not match the pinion gears on the other side, there may have been nothing wrong with the motors. Have you tested the motors to see if one or both are bad? Any bad motors should go in the trash immediately to prevent tripping up someone later.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
philso:

Did you check the pinion gears?

Plerion:

the right side motor set goes slower than the left side but only when going forward.

Wouldnâ€™t a different-sized pinion have cause equal (or at least similar) issues both in forward and reverse?

posts.name: Mike Taylor (he/him)
posts.cooked: One would think so, but thatâ€™s not what we found.  One direction was much more pronounced than the other (I donâ€™t recall which).
